Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Mark Grinstaff from Boston University (BU) will acquire a micro-MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer (micro-MALDI-TOF). The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) electrochemistry of diheme cytochrome c peroxidases; (b) bacteriophobic coatings for inhibition of pathogenic biofilms; (c) synthesis and reactivity of polyaromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) belts; (d) improvement of nanoparticle functionalization strategies; and (e) studies of inhibitors and activators of protein-protein interactions.

Mass Spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. A critical gap exists in the current mass spectrometric capabilities on the BU Charles River Campus because there is no instrument of the type needed to support chemical research in the life processes, chemistry and nanotechnology. The new instrument on the Charles River Campus would directly and immediately impact and enhance the projects of more than 40 graduate, 10 undergraduate, and 10 post-doctoral researchers. The new instrument would be available to other scientists and educators at BU, as well as outside institutions such as Emmanuel College, with whom BU has partnered in advancing education and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Boston University Department of Chemistry on the Charles River Campus (BU CRC) requested funds from the NSF MRI Program for the purchase of a Bruker Autoflex Matrix Assisted Laser Desorption Ionization Time-of-Flight (MALDI-TOF) Mass Spectrometer. The compact, user friendly, and high-resolution MALDI-TOF is housed and maintained in the Chemical Instrumentation Center (CIC). The instrument and software have enabled the work of faculty, postdoctoral research associates, graduate students, and undergraduates in the Departments of Chemistry, Biology and Biomedical Engineering.

 

The MALDI-TOF is needed to support chemical research in the life processes, including the areas of dendritic and linear polymers, proteins and peptides, novel synthetic organic materials, and nano-particles. These research groups are now benefiting from having access on campus rather than submitting their samples to external institutions that was not only expensive, but also caused delays in research, and risked damage to sensitive samples during the transportation process. The MALDI-TOF instrument has directly impacted more than 20 graduate, 10 undergraduate, and 10 post-doctoral researchers. In addition, the instrument has been incorporated in an undergraduate instrumentation analysis lab course (300-level) and in 3 years, more than 45 students have gained hands-on experience in sample preparation, performing the experiment and interpreting results.

 

In addition to the BU instructional and research community, the MALDI-TOF has also been used by outreach programs hosted on BU CRC, such as Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship (SURF) and Community College students and summer REU students in the Chemistry Department Program (NSF CHE1560152).  These programs were designed to provide access to talented non-BU undergraduate students, especially those from minority groups traditionally under-represented in the sciences (e.g., African-American, Hispanic, Native American). Through those programs, 6 students have gained experience on the MALDI-TOF.

 

The training of young scientists in the use of mass spectrometry will not only facilitate their own research objectives, but will also provide them with additional technical skills for succeeding in their future careers in academia, government, or industry.  On behalf BU and the research communities on BU, we’d like to thank NSF MRI for supporting us.
